comments.author: rcroxall@htec.co.uk
comments.text:
User Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; WOW64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/51.0.2704.84 Safari/537.36

Steps to reproduce:

Using Angular-JS Videogular I wrote HTML video HTML (up to 8 per page) as follows:
<video type="video/mp4" src="/api/mediastream/1182"><track label="English" srclang="en" kind="subtitles" src="http://www.videogular.com/assets/subs/pale-blue-dot.vtt"></video>


Actual results:

Firefox requests first part of video with range:

Range: bytes=0-

My server supplies first 1,000,000 bytes of video:
Content-Length: 1000000
Content-Range: bytes 0-999999/5051602

Firefox never requests any more and stops when it has played first page.


Expected results:

Like IE/Chrome, Firefox should have requested the next part with range:

Range: bytes=1000000-

Previous version (not sure whether 45 or 46) would request the entire video (without a range - which I can now supply).
comments.creator: rcroxall@htec.co.uk

comments.text:
My priority at the moment is changing the JavaScript code to work around the problem by checking whether the browser is Firefox and request another URL which will then send the whole video regardless whether a range is requested. 

Even if you were to fix this bug immediately, there will be copies of Firefox 47 in the field which will still need to work, so I need a work around.

This should be relatively easy to find as this appears to be a new bug in this or the previous release. 

Do you not have unit tests for firefox which should have detected this problem?
comments.author: rcroxall@htec.co.uk
comments.creator: rcroxall@htec.co.uk
comments.raw_text:
My priority at the moment is changing the JavaScript code to work around the problem by checking whether the browser is Firefox and request another URL which will then send the whole video regardless whether a range is requested. 

Even if you were to fix this bug immediately, there will be copies of Firefox 47 in the field which will still need to work, so I need a work around.

This should be relatively easy to find as this appears to be a new bug in this or the previous release. 

Do you not have unit tests for firefox which should have detected this problem?

comments.text: My workaround doesn't work properly either. When Firefox 47 asks for a video range (Range: bytes=0- ), I send the whole video. Sending the whole video used to work as Firefox 45 would preview the video before all of it had arrived. Now unfortunately Firefox 47 seems to wait for the whole video to arrive before you can see any of it. This can be several minutes!!
comments.author: rcroxall@htec.co.uk
comments.creator: rcroxall@htec.co.uk
comments.raw_text: My workaround doesn't work properly either. When Firefox 47 asks for a video range (Range: bytes=0- ), I send the whole video. Sending the whole video used to work as Firefox 45 would preview the video before all of it had arrived. Now unfortunately Firefox 47 seems to wait for the whole video to arrive before you can see any of it. This can be several minutes!!

If you can't provide a live testcase, put the the video and files (css, etc) in archive, then attach it to the bug report.

It will hard to find a regression range without testcase.

comments.author: rcroxall@htec.co.uk
comments.text:
The full thing requires 2 blocks of server code in C#, Angular-JS, CSS & HTML, a SQL server database containing the videos and about 30 other tables and the code is proprietary for a commercial website, so even if I wanted to and was allowed to, it will still be far too complicated.

I'm looking for a cut down version which still shows the problem.
comments.creator: rcroxall@htec.co.uk
comments.raw_text:
The full thing requires 2 blocks of server code in C#, Angular-JS, CSS & HTML, a SQL server database containing the videos and about 30 other tables and the code is proprietary for a commercial website, so even if I wanted to and was allowed to, it will still be far too complicated.

I'm looking for a cut down version which still shows the problem.

This is a VS2015 C# server which demonstrates the issue.
I'm running on Windows 7 using VS2015 - update 1.
When the server is running enter the URL:
http://localhost:58274/test3.html
This clearly demonstrates that Firefox asks for a range 0-.
My server returns the first 1,000,000 of the video.
However when firefox gets the video gets to this point, it does not ask for any more video and the video stops.
comments.creator: rcroxall@htec.co.uk
comments.author: rcroxall@htec.co.uk
comments.text:
Created attachment 8764184
Firefox tester written in C# to prove video range never requests rest of video (with packages and video removed)

This is a VS2015 C# server which demonstrates the issue.
I'm running on Windows 7 using VS2015 - update 1.
When the server is running enter the URL:
http://localhost:58274/test3.html
This clearly demonstrates that Firefox asks for a range 0-.
My server returns the first 1,000,000 of the video.
However when firefox gets the video gets to this point, it does not ask for any more video and the video stops.

comments.raw_text:
I spent a happy day creating a new Web service in VS2015 update 1.
I copied and pasted all the relevant code from my other systems and was able to duplicate the issue.

Unfortunately my 400Mb zip file exceeded the 10Mb limit by a factor of 40.
So I had to remove the videos and the packages.
VS2015 update 1 seems to add the packages back on startup using NuGet.
Unfortunately you will have to supply your own 8 videos (which are over 1,000,000 bytes long) and name them on lines 36-43 in MediaProvider.cs.

To demonstrate the issue, 
1) start Fiddler to monitor the network traffic.
2) Provide your own 8 videos and place them in the "movie" folder.
3) Start VS2015-update 1 and using FFTester.sln
4) Name your videos in MediaProvider.cs.
5) debug program.
6) It starts IE11 which works ok.
7) Add test3.html to the end of the URL and go to page
8) 8 Videos arrive and play ok.
9) paste URL into Firefox and go to page.
10) FF requests range starting at 0.
11) Server (following standards) honours the request and provides 1,000,000 as a range.
12) FF displays videos, but only plays first 1,000,000 and stops at the end without requesting another range starting at 1,000,000.

I hope this is sufficient for you guys to believe there is a bug, find the bug and fix it as soon as you can.
A statement that this IS a bug that I can give to my boss would be great.
Also if you have any workarounds different to that used in test2.html and test4.html, that would be even better.
Thanks.
comments.creator: rcroxall@htec.co.uk

comments.raw_text:
When I tried to restart the project, the paths to the packages were all incorrect (..\packages rather than packages). I don't know how that happened, but I presume the previous submission won't build in that state.
So the attached project file has manually corrected path to the packages which now seems to work ok.
comments.creator: rcroxall@htec.co.uk

So the attached project file has manually corrected path to the packages which now seems to work ok.

comments.raw_text:
Hi Abe,
Contrary to my memory, your regression test utility shows the bug present in versions 45 and 44.

The bug is simple.
Firefox requests a Video range.
Server provides first part of range.
Firefox plays first part of range
Firefox never requests rest of video range.

Not sure what to do now.
comments.creator: rcroxall@htec.co.uk
comments.author: rcroxall@htec.co.uk
